page.title: 19ORNITHOLOGY OF BREDON HILL
page.content: Anyone walking over the hill could almost guarantee to hear and see thrushes, blackbirds, chaffinches and robins at any time. In spring and early summer, to these would be added swallows, swifts, sandmartins, willow warblers, whitethroats, wrens, yellow buntings (hammers), blackcaps, linnets green and spotted woodpeckers, many kinds of tits, larks, tree creepers, goldfinches, greenfinches, collard doves, pheasants, partridges, cuckoos, screach owls, little owls and the occasional barn owl. In autumn fieldfares and red wings are common. Less common are kestrels, buzzards, stock doves, curlews and plovers.Meadow pipits and redstarts have been seen and a hobby hawk is thought to have nested. Bullfinches are fairly common but are not welcomed by the farmers.
